Everyone was expecting a reset from BASF, as demonstrated by the price above. Management's optimism was looking increasingly detached from sanity over the past few months.

BE11:13am

However! What a reset!

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Let me cut to Goldman for the summary.

BE11:13am

BASF announced a cut to FY19 guidance (July 8), on the back of continued automotive weakness, the weak planting season in North America, and unresolved US-China trade tensions. BASF noted uncertainty remains high, and does not expect any real improvement in the macro for 2H19 (new guidance of up to 30% lower y/y implies 2H down a maximum of 18% y/y).

BE11:14am

Just the 20% worse than consensus then.

11:13 am
BE11:14am

New FY19 guidance: BASF now expects FY19 EBIT before
nspecial items to be up to 30% below the prior year level vs. previous guidance of a slight increase y/y (+1-10%). We currently forecast EBIT to decline 10% y/y, with Vara Research consensus sitting at -7%. On sales, BASF’s guidance was updated to a slight decline y/y, vs. a slight increase y/y vs. consensus expectations for c.2% increase (on sales “slight” implies 1-5% for BASF).

BE11:14am

Preliminary 2Q19 figures: EBIT before special items are
nexpected to be €1 bn i.e. 47% lower y/y, and 32% below Vara Research consensus estimates. According to the release, the decline was mostly driven by the large volume businesses (Materials and Chemicals), as well as weakness in Ag. With preliminary sales expected -4% y/y in the quarter, the implied EBIT margin is 270bp lower than consensus expected (6.6% vs. 9.3% Vara).

BE11:14am

We also note a €500mn none-off charge below the line (consensus was at €165mn) which the company attributed to: 1) costs related to implementation of its cost excellence savings program, and 2) an impairment

Viking1 How much does DWS own of Basf ? Good old Deutsche Bank !!
11:14 am
BE11:14am

The key point to make here is that we're not in a recession yet.

BE11:18am

11:18 am
BE11:19am

Every conversation that we've had with the company over the last few months has centred on the outlook, and there is no question that the assumptions inherent in the guidance were clearly stated and that excuses are readily available ‒ eg trade war resolution, Brexit, weaker-than-expected industrial production growth. However, we think there is a line between financial guidance using 'optimistic' assumptions and guidance that uses 'aspirational' assumptions. The latter has fairly limited utility or credibility, in our view.

Shinshin BASF is wide ranging chemicals, no ? Not a single specialist target market. Are the sales going to competitors or is it shrinking market ?
Soundbuy I'm still pending, yeah, yeah, yeah........
BE11:19am

The guidance cut lowers the bar and rebases expectations. Some form of guidance cut was in the numbers, but with a 30% decline, the stock is now at 10.1x EBITDA and no longer cheap with earnings at their lowest level since 2012. Profits have collapsed, and it’s not even a recession; the second profit warning in seven months raises questions around credibility. Progressive dividend maintained and the cover for it is adequate, but offers scant comfort from a valuation standpoint. We cut our 2019 EBIT and net profit estimates by 23-30%, broadly in line with company’s profit warning guidance. We reduce our target price to EUR61 from EUR75 and downgrade to Hold from Buy.

BE11:21am

(@Soundbuy: I don't run the f____g moderation system. I can, however, pause the show for five minutes to pull you out of spam filter purgatory. Which is what has just happened.)

Blank canvas BE, if you have time, anything brokerage comment on Bovis please

BE11:22am

And JPMorgan, making the same point as @Shinshin over there.

Grouchmonkey Is any part of the slowdown due to that row/litigation over glyphosate?
BE11:23am

Notwithstanding the softer macro, the magnitude of 2Q19 and FY19 profit warning within a span of three months shows that the BASF business model offers no obvious benefit from being almost everything to everybody in the sector. We see this as a further argument for the company to seriously consider optimizing and simplifying the portfolio. Prior to the warning, we had been of the opinion that one should be a buyer of this expected profit warning. However, given the magnitude of cuts to estimates, our view that there now seems to be no easy way out of this earnings malaise – partly
symptomatic of a business model that has failed to inspire confidence in recent times – and the rising dividend sustainability risk are enough reasons for us to rescind our optimism for now. Hence, we downgrade the stock to Neutral.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

We cut our FY19E/20E adj EBIT by 20%/19%, adj EPS by 20%/21% and PT by 18% to €59 (€72). Based on a historical trough TTM P/B multiple of 1.4x, we think the potential trough could be ~€52 in the near term.

red @Shinshinbasf pretty good barometer in general
BE11:23am

Dividend sustainability concerns to rise: Our new lowered FY19E/20E FCF of €2.1bn/€2.2bn is lower than the current annual dividend of €2.9bn. This might raise market concerns on the sustainability of the current annual dividend if there is no quick pickup in macro. This also given the ND/EBITDA will be 2.4x at '19e end based on our new estimates.

We reduce our Covestro EBITDA by an average ~10% throughout the forecast period (mark to market product spreads and more moderate volume assumptions). We reduce our target price to €48/share and maintain our NEUTRAL rating. Our FY19F EBITDA (~€1.6bn) is ~10% below consensus and at the lower end of the company guidance (EBITDA €1.5-2bn).

BE11:31am

With stocks up in June and manufacturing PMIs down, the set-up in Q2 results was challenged and Hexagon’s profit warning on July 5 provided the trigger for some profit taking. Our June CEO conference did not indicate a step change in trading in Q2 but the June run rate may indicate downside to H2 2019/2020 expectations. PMIs could improve post the summer on completed inventory adjustment, but it may be difficult for the sector to perform in the near term. We are awaiting updated consensus for a number of companies but as of now our estimates are ahead or we are comfortable holding the following stocks into the Q2 results: Prysmian, Schneider, Siemens and Melrose. We see more elevated risks to estimates or valuation at ABB, Bodycote, FLSmidth, Sandvik, Siemens Gamesa, Vestas and Wärtsilä.

FATDAZ @BE Morgan Stanley cited concerns about the earnings outlook as one of the reason for their downgrade of equities yesterday
11:31 am
BE11:32am

We expect Melrose to show resilience in
automotive despite the challenging backdrop, an important marker on the
opportunity at GKN, and strong progress in Aerospace. At Weir, we expect a
weaker development in Oil & Gas compared to consensus but believe investor
expectations are already lowered and we expect a strong development in mining. Spectris has a significant H2 weighting to earnings on our model and
we struggle to see the Interims as a catalyst coming so soon after the CMD. We
are similarly cautious on Bodycote, where we see auto and general industrial
weakness persisting and putting pressure on margins, despite aerospace
strength, and see increased risk for H2. The set-up is tricky to call at Rotork
where we expect a H1 earnings beat but see optically weak orders/sales and the
H2 weighting as reason for caution on the results. We do not expect any
surprises at Spirax-Sarco with another strong period expected; our forecasts
are low single-digits ahead of consensus for the full-year. We are close to fullyear
consensus at IMI with H1 challenges understood and the potential for
Critical Engineering to improve in H2. We expect only limited strategic
comments from new CEO at this stage.

U/P: KONE, EPIA, WRT & d/g SKF, SXS. Init KBX w/ U/P.

BE11:44am

Key numbers:

· 1H19 EBITDA pre-exceptionals: £18.7mn, vs Barclays £26.1mn.

· The ‘miss’ was driven by ‘Other’, which was caused by the higher share price impacting compensation costs.

· 1H19 Retail EBITDA: £44.1mn, vs Barclays £45.5mn.

· 1H19 Solutions EBITDA: £(16.2)mn, vs Barclays £(17.3)mn.

· Active customer numbers were up +9.7% to 745k (679k in 1H18).

· Volume growth of 10.4% to an average of 318k per week (288k OPW in 1H18).

· Deliveries Per Van Per Week have risen to 194 (from 189 in 1H18).

· Average Ocado.com basket size fell by -0.1% to £108.04 (from £108.18 in 1H last year).

BE11:44am

First Impressions:

· Ocado said the estimated impact of the fire at CFC3 in February was c2% over the first half as a whole.

· Income from suppliers increased by +16.8% to £39.7 (£34.0 in 1H) and it represents over 4% of sales.

· CFC3 is being rebuilt with a new state of the art facility and is expected to go live in late 2021/early 2022. CFC4 capacity has been increased by more than 50% in the period. Construction for CFC5, in Purfleet, will also commence soon.

Guidance:

· Retail revenue growth of 10-15% in 2H.

· Capex guidance of £350mn remains unchanged.

· Ocado highlights two material impacts to FY19 EBITDA: 1) £15mn impact from the fire at CFC3 (£8mn is related to reduced fees and higher fixed costs as a result of the Morrison’s arrangement on capacity at CFC4; £7mn from Retail sales lost due to the fire). 2) £10mn impact on Other EBITDA from share schemes.

· Ocado states – other than the £25mn above – that it is on course to deliver FY19 EBITDA in-line with market expectations. Ocado’s website lists consensus at £45.3mn, indicating Ocado expects FY19 EBITDA at c£20mn.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

As it pushes through to becoming The Microsoft of Retail, Ocado’s fees from its deals increased by 36% in H1 2019 £123m, with international fees almost doubling. This is the KPI that investors should focus on as Ocado Group makes the dramatic transformation from a transactional online retailer to a software and deep tech hardware business. Its largest client to date, Ocado.com, grew +9.7% yoy, despite the fire. EBITDA outlook for the year unchanged, except for two cash-neutral items: the fire will be covered by insurance and share-based payments due to a strong equity performance. With its Ventures arm continuing to invest in complementary, adjacent, and brand new tech, funded by the success of its first innovation (including its deal with M&S), it feels like Ocado could be turning into Alphabet.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Jefferies:

BE11:50am

OCDO's interims confirmed the impact on ST profit expectations of: 1) the Andover fire hurting retail sales fully in Q2 (with the MRW capacity agreement hurting costs from H2); 2) Solutions opex up strongly given a ramp up in OSP roll-out; 3) Central costs stepped up by exec compensation. Following new guidance, there is likely to be a sizeable cut to current FY19 cons EBITDA of £45m (JEFe £49m). Cashflow drivers to consider at the meeting include: 1) how much of the current OSP capex is development vs implementation? 2) what is the normalised rate of central costs growth? 3) what is the exact launch date for Monoprix/Sobeys in 2020?. Zoom will certainly take centre stage. For several reasons, we doubt it is significantly accretive to the investment case. The equity prices in a very unlikely level of longterm future cashflow success.

1966AndAllThat @squarepeg yes it (and the associated electrolysers) is the goto technology for storing and using renewables. Australia doing some great work on Ammonia as storage and transport and Ceres works on green ammonia. Better than batteries for Lorries / Trains / Planes as cheaper with high energydensity and zero emmissions. However the university offshoots have a mixed record of commercialising their technology and worried that their recent JV with China may mean their technology goes walkabout

BE12:03pm

VIRGIN GALACTIC AND SOCIAL CAPITAL HEDOSOPHIA ANNOUNCE MERGER TO CREATE THE WORLD’S FIRST AND ONLY PUBLICLY TRADED COMMERCIAL HUMAN SPACEFLIGHT COMPANY

BE12:04pm

Uh.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

New York, USA (July 9, 2019): VIRGIN GALACTIC (“VG”) and SOCIAL CAPITAL HEDOSOPHIA (“SCH”), a public investment vehicle sponsored by Social Capital and Hedosophia, announced that the boards of directors of each company have approved a definitive agreement under which VG and SCH will merge, with the current shareholders of SCH expected to own up to approximately 49% of the combined company. Upon closing of the transaction, which is expected in the second half of 2019, VG will be introduced as the first and only publicly traded commercial human spaceflight company.

BE12:05pm

Okay, I missed this. It's a hermit crab move into a vehicle set up by former Facebooker Chamath Palihapitiya?
